Nepal has been facing a difficult situation over the last two years. The 
economy experienced a sharp downturn from the impact of a series of 
internal  shocks,  deterioration  in  the  domestic  security  situation, 
political instability, and adverse developments in the global economy. 
The  economic  scenario  deteriorated  sharply  in  fiscal  year  (FY)  2002, 
with  a  negative  growth  rate  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  that

(10FYP)  covering  FY2003–FY2007,  which  is  also  the  Government’s 
poverty reduction strategy (PRS).

The PSMP assumes that the fiscal situation will not deteriorate further 
to  require  a  bigger  cut  in  development  expenditure,  and  thereby 
adversely affect the implementation of the poverty reduction strategy.

little  control.  Alternatively,  weak  domestic  economic  performance

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT  

Current Macroeconomic Problems  

 
A. 
 
2. 
 Nepal has been facing a sharp economic downturn since mid-2001 from the impacts of 
internal  shocks,  especially  the  deaths  of  members  of  the  royal  family  in  June  2001  and  the 
upsurge  of  the  conflict  with  the  Underground  Communist  Party  of  Nepal/Maoist (CPN/M). The 
economic scenario further deteriorated in FY2002 due to the 11 September events in the United 
States,  the  global  economic  slowdown,  and  the  continued  escalation  of  insurgency  and  the 
resulting political instability. These disruptions adversely affected the performance of a number 
of key sectors, especially manufacturing, tourism, and exports. Gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth  declined  sharply  and  the  Government’s  finances  came  under  severe  strain.  The 
deteriorating  economic  situation  coincided  with  the  initiation  of  the  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan 
(10FYP) covering FY2003–FY 2007, which is also the Government’s poverty reduction strategy 
(PRS).  The  current  economic  situation  is  severely  constraining  the  Government’s  capacity  to 
pursue a coherent poverty reduction agenda outlined in the 10FYP. 
 
3. 
GDP growth in FY2001 remained favorable although it slipped to 4.6% from the target of 
6%.  Economic  performance  deteriorated  precipitously  in  FY2002,  with  economic  growth 
estimated at minus 0.5% due to the worsening internal security situation, unfavorable weather 
conditions, and weak external demand. The agriculture sector grew by 2.2%, down from 5.5% in 
FY2001,  due  to  irregular  monsoon  rains  in  June–August  2001.  The  performance  of  exports, 
tourism, and domestic manufacturing was also poor. These sectors were particularly hard hit by 
domestic insurgency as well as by the global economic slowdown. 
 
4. 
Exports declined by 18% in FY2002 after an annual average growth of 21% during the 
last  3  years.  Key  merchandise  exports  such  as  woolen  carpets,  ready-made garments, and 
pashmina products declined significantly due to supply disruptions as well as the slowdown in 
demand  abroad.  Simultaneously,  tourist  arrivals  in  FY2002  declined  by  about  40%,  which 
resulted in an estimated 34% decline in receipts from tourism, a major source of the country’s 
foreign exchange earnings. 
 
5. 
The impact of the slowdown in exports and tourism on the overall balance of payments 
was  more  than  offset  by  a  drop  in  imports  and  a  steady  growth  of  workers’  remittances  from 
abroad.  Imports  are  estimated  to  have  declined  by  about  11.4%  in  FY2002  due  to  lower 
demand  for  industrial  raw  materials,  lower  oil  prices,  and  reduced  aid-related  imports. 
Remittances, on the other hand, increased by 14.8% due to the increased number of workers 
going  abroad.  As  a  consequence,  the  surplus  on  current  account  of  the  balance  of  payments 
increased  from  1%  of  GDP  in  FY2001  to  2.6%  of  GDP  in  FY2002.  The  overall  balance  of 
payments is estimated to have worsened from a surplus of $37 million in FY2001 to a deficit of 
$32  million  in  FY2002  due  to  a  significant  decline  in  foreign  loans  (a  drop  of  about  32%  in

B. 

Short- to Medium-Term Macroeconomic Outlook 

 

  Macroeconomic  prospects  in  the  short  to  medium  term  depend  largely  on  how  the 
7. 
security and political scenarios develop. Current indications are that the security situation should 
improve as the Government and the CPN/M are making a serious effort to reach a negotiated 
settlement. Assuming an improved security situation, and considering the sectoral trends in the 
current year, GDP growth in FY2003 is projected at around 2%. This is considerably lower than 
the  targets  of  the  10FYP  (paras.  10–14).  Despite  some  signs  of  recovery,  manufacturing  is 
expected  to  remain  depressed  until  the  security  problems  are  resolved.  Uncertainties  about 
external demand in both India and third countries are also affecting the sector’s output. A major 
upturn  in  tourism  is  unlikely  unless  the  security  environment  significantly  improves.  Growth  in 
agriculture will continue to depend on the vagaries of weather.  
 
8. 
Given  these  uncertainties,  it  is  doubtful  whether  the  Government  could  mobilize 
adequate resources for implementing the poverty reduction program of the 10FYP. The FY2003

Successful  implementation  of  the  10FYP  depends  on  certain  key  assumptions,  and

restoration  of  internal  law  and  order  could  take  longer  than  currently  estimated,  resource

lower growth and social sector investments, poverty reduction would be significantly lower.

Over the last 2 years, the Government has adopted several measures aimed at reducing 
tax-induced  distortions,  strengthening  tax  administration,  and  making  the  tax  laws  and 
procedures simpler and more transparent. The Income Tax Act of 2001 broadened the tax base 
significantly,  rationalized  the  tax  structure  by  reducing  the  number  of  tax  slabs  to  two,  and 
established  neutrality  of  taxation  in  various  income-generating  activities.  A  self-assessment 
system  for  taxpayers  has  been  implemented  to  further  streamline  tax  administration. 
Amendments  have  been  made  to  the  VAT  Act,  which  now  requires  better  maintenance  of 
records  and  has  more  explicit  penal  provisions  for  noncompliance.    VAT  coverage  has  been 
expanded to include services and retail trade enterprises. Similarly, the Excise Act of 2002 aims 
at  harmonizing  and  updating  excise  administration  and  expanding  the  coverage  of  the  excise 
net. A Customs Act amendment has been drafted to implement the World Trade Organization 
(WTO) valuation system and to reform customs administration. The structure of key taxes has 
been rationalized: the maximum marginal tax rate for the personal income tax and the corporate 
tax has been set at 25% (banks, financial institutions, insurance and petroleum companies pay 
a maximum marginal tax rate of 30%), there are seven slabs of customs tariffs5 although over 
75% of imports are taxed at 15% or less, and there is a single VAT rate of 10%.

Poor  Governance  and  Profitability  of  PEs.  Most  of  Nepal’s  PEs  were  established  in 
the 1960s and 1970s. Management and supervision are assigned to the various line ministries, 
a significant number of which are under the Ministry of Commerce and Industries. The Ministry

24. 
Financial  and  operational  information  on  PEs  is  largely  unaudited;  as  a  result,  the 
existing financial information is often of doubtful quality. The published records of MOF currently 
include 39 PEs under full Government ownership, with reported assets of about NRs198 billion 
($2.5 billion), and total employment of 46,000.6 Lack of reliable and up-to-date accounts reflects 
the  Government’s  incoherent  approach  to  maintain  its  ownership  mandate.  The  line  ministries 
tend  to  interfere  in  the  PEs’  day-to-day  operations,  while  relevant  legal  provisions  are  either 
absent, or not enforced, to ensure rule-based supervision by PE boards. Political appointees on 
boards  have  undermined  the  latter’s  independence,  precluded  commercial  orientation,  and 
hampered  the  development  of  a  professional  culture  on  the  boards.  Frequent  changes  in 
Government  have  resulted  in  unstable  board  composition,  politicization,  and  appointment  of 
management  and  staff  on  nonprofessional  considerations.  The  result  is  significant  over-
employment  and  staff  redundancy.  In  the  absence  of  clear  objectives  and  controls,  PE 
managers  have  little  incentive  to  adhere  to  sound  corporate  governance  principles.  As  a 
consequence, PEs are subject to rent seeking by their staff and the line ministries.

In  recent  years,  the  Government  has  adopted  several  key  reform  measures  aimed  at 
1. 
reducing tax-induced distortions, strengthening tax administration, and making the tax laws and

tax  regime  and  promotes  neutrality  of  taxation  in  various  income-generating  activities.  The 
major features of the Act include measures to check transfer-pricing and to expand the tax net 
by  including  export  earnings,  dividends,  pensions,  foreign  earnings  from  insurance,  and 
provident fund deposits. The number of tax slabs has been reduced to 2, compared with 10 a

discretionary  power  in  customs  valuation.  This  measure  is  also  expected  to  bring  customs

2. 
The  legislative  environment  for  state-owned  enterprise  reform  is  currently  governed  by 
the Privatization Act (1994). The Act provides for a Privatization Committee (PC) with executive 
powers  to  propose  candidates  for  privatization.  Once  these  proposals  are  sanctioned  by 
Cabinet, the PC is responsible for implementation leading to the conclusion of negotiations with 
a prospective bidder. The matter is then submitted to the Cabinet for final approval. The PC is 
empowered  to  establish  subcommittees.  According  to  the  Act,  the  PC  will  define  the  terms  of 
reference for the subcommittees. In the past individual subcommittees were tasked with taking 
forward  technical  work  for  each  privatization  candidate.  As  defined  in  the  Act,  the  PC  is 
composed of 11 members: minister of state for finance, chairman; chairman, finance committee 
(House of Representatives); two members of Parliament designated by Government; member, 
National  Planning  Commission;  secretary,  Ministry  of  Finance  (MOF);  secretary,  Ministry  of 
Law,  Justice  and  Parliamentary  Affairs;  secretary,  Ministry  of  Labor;  secretary  of  the  line 
ministry of the PE to be privatized; president, Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce 
and  Industry;  and  Joint  Secretary,  MOF  (Corporation  Coordination  Division)  as  member-
secretary.

Civil Service  

 
1. 
The Government of Nepal has increasingly recognized that economic growth cannot be 
achieved  or  sustained  without  good  governance.  This  is  particularly  true  in  Nepal  where 
institutions  are  weak,  incentive  structures  are  distorted,  and  people’s  participation  in  policy 
making  is  weak.  Therefore,  governance  reform  has  remained  a  key  element  in  the 
Government’s  economic  and  structural  reform  program,  which  seeks  to  sustain  accelerated 
growth  and  economic  stability.  Governance  reform  involves  a  host  of  issues  including 
empowering  people,  devolving  power  to  grassroot  organizations,  enhancing  transparency  in 
government activities, calling public officials to task for their actions, and ensuring predictability 
in  government  and  consistency  in  application  of  rules.  Accordingly,  the  Government  has 
prioritized reforms in the areas of civil service, decentralization, and combating corruption.  
 
2. 
The  FY2003  Budget  spells  out  the  Government’s  policy  on  governance.  The  Civil 
Service  Reform  Program  will  be  continued  to  make  the  civil  service  responsible,  accountable, 
and  efficient;  and  to  eliminate  unnecessary  vacant  positions.  In  the  area  of  decentralization, 
sources  of  revenue  that  can  be  devolved  to  local  bodies  will  be  identified,  block  grants  to  the 
local  bodies  will  be  linked  to  poverty  level,  and  local  bodies  will  need  to  make  mandatory 
quarterly  public  reports.  As  part  of  its  initiatives  to  control  corruption,  the  Government  will 
prepare  a  comprehensive  anticorruption  strategy  and  will  start  implementing  it  in  FY2004.  In 
addition,  additional  manpower  and  resources  will  be  made  available  to  constitutional  entities 
engaged in corruption control.  
 
A. 
 
3. 
The civil service in Nepal was originally established for land administration, collection of 
land  revenue,  maintenance  of  law  and  order,  and  dispensation  of  justice.  The  present  civil 
service  is  governed  by  the  1998  Civil  Service  Act  and  Civil  Service  Rules.  The  Nepalese  civil 
service  consists  of  10  services:  administrative;  agriculture;  economic  planning  and  statistical; 
education; engineering; forest; health; judicial; miscellaneous; and parliamentary.1 The total size 
of  Nepal’s  civil  service  is  estimated  at  103,000  approved  posts,  of  which  about  86,000  are 
currently  occupied.  Approximately  90%  of  civil  servants  are  in  the  nongazetted  (support  staff) 
class,  and  of  this  group,  almost  35%  are  cleaning  staff  and  messengers.  There  are 
approximately  0.57  civil  servant  per  100  population,  which  is  low  by  developing  country 
standards, considering that only 10% of the civil servants are at officer level.   
 
Women are underrepresented in the civil service. They account for only about 8.6% of

promoted  to  class  one.  The  trend  is  similar  at  all  levels,  indicating  that  cultural  stereotypes

women’s interests.

8. 
A  series  of  legislation  on  decentralization  were  approved  between  1965  and  1982,  but 
they  were  confined  to  deconcentrating  the  administrative  system  to  district  level,  under  an 
elected,  but  nonparty  model  of  governance.  Decentralized  governance  is  one  of  the  guiding 
principles  embodied  in  the  Constitution  of  the  Kingdom  of  Nepal  in  1990.  The  main  goal  is  to 
strengthen  multiparty  democracy  and  poverty  reduction.  Successive  governments  after  1990 
have  given  impetus  to  decentralization  with  the  result  that  the  Local  Self-Governance  Act 
(LSGA) of 1999 and Local Self-Governance Regulations have come into force.  
 
9. 
The  Ninth  Plan  and  the  LSGA  offered  a  policy  and  regulatory  framework  on 
decentralization and local governance. Although this framework sets a process of devolution, it 
has  not  been  adequately  supported  by  financial  and  human  resources  necessary  for  enabling 
the  local  bodies  to  undertake  their  prescribed  functions.  The  Public  Expenditure  Review 
Commission  in  November  2000  recommended  streamlining  of  the  poverty  focus  and

them  ownership  of  program  implementation.  There  are  provisions  to  tie  up  the  block  grants  to

implementing  various  targeted  programs  so  as  to  uplift  the  living  condition  of  poor, 
disadvantaged, ethnic, and women’s and children’s groups. It also provides for the development 
of  an  effective  monitoring  system  for  assessing  the  outreach  of  allocated  fund  to  the  targeted 
groups and to develop a community-auditing system for such programs.  
  
13. 
On 15 July 2002, the Government decided that the responsibilities of local bodies would 
be  handed  over  to  the  civil  service  bureaucracy  when  the  5-year  terms  of  the  local  bodies 
expired  on  16  July  2002.  Many  regarded  this  decision  as  against  the  overall  spirit  of 
empowering  local  governments  and  counter  to  the  spirit  of  democracy  and  decentralization. It 
undermines  the  work  and  support  provided  by  numerous  aid  agencies  to  strengthen  local 
governance,  including  implementation  of  the  DIP.  On  15  August  2002,  the  Government 
established  various  committees  (comprising  civil  servants)  at  different  levels  of  local 
government to undertake the functions performed by elected bodies. 
 
14.

in  part  because  the  elected  local  bodies  were  replaced  with  civil  service  committees. Civil 
servants  working  in  local  bodies  have  complained  that  they  lack  the  legal  provision  and 
experience  in  running  the  local  government.  Nongazetted  staff,  for  example,  have  been 
assigned  to  make  recommendations  for  citizenship  certificates  and  relationship certificates. In 
addition,  civil  servants  are  over-burdened  for  they  have  to  undertake  jobs  that  were  earlier 
handled by a large number of local representatives. The absence of about 1,000 secretaries in 
many  village  development  committees  has  aggravated  the  situation  and  negatively  affected

15. 
Governance  reform  is  unrealistic  in  the  presence  of  rampant  corruption.  In  the  case  of 
Nepal,  it  has  often  been  said  that  corruption  is  a  systemic  problem  that  undermines  the 
performance  of  the  bureaucracy  and  the  Government  as  a  whole.  It  is  alleged  that  there  is 
uncontrolled  growth  of  corruption  in  high  places  and  low,  and  in  politics,  bureaucracy,  public 
enterprises (PEs), business, etc. The five administrative reform commission reports from 1951 
to  1992  have  consistently  identified  the  prevalence  of  corruption  and  suggested  actions  to 
overcome  this  weakness.  Although  legislation,  institutional  arrangements,  and  mechanisms 
exist  for  corruption  control,  they  have  remained  ineffective.  In  the  past,  commissions  and 
studies (e.g., Mahadev Yadav Commission, Acharya Task Force, and the study on  Causes and 
Consequences  of  Corruption  in  Nepal by Baivab Consultancy Service and Environment Study 
Center)  have  recommended  amendments  to  existing  legislation  and  introduction  of  new 
legislation as major steps to reduce corruption.  

 
16. 
The  21st  session  of  the  House  of  Representatives  unanimously  approved  four 
anticorruption bills: Anti-Corruption Bill (amendment), Commission for Investigation of Abuse of 
Authority (CIAA) Bill (second amendment), Impeachment Bill, and Special Court Bill on 17 April 
2002. Deliberation on amendments to the CIAA Act and Anti-Corruption Act was initiated in the 
16th  session  of  the  Parliament,  and  amendment  to  the  CIAA  Act  was  tabled  in  Parliament  in 
1998.  It  took  4  years  for  the  amendments  to  be  legislated.  New  provisions  have  been 
incorporated  in  the  anticorruption  legislation,  which  should  have  an  overall  positive  impact  on 
the anticorruption efforts of the Government. Several important features of the new bills are: a 
clear definition of corruption, which makes it difficult for the accused to get away; activities that 
constitute corruption clearly spelled out; wide range of penalty provisions for the bribe taker and 
the giver as well; provision of additional penalties for senior public persons; role, responsibilities, 
and  accountability  of  Investigation  Officer  defined;  cases  against  retired  personnel  can  be 
registered at any time, if required; considerably widened scope and authority of CIAA; provision 
for hiring of private lawyers by CIAA; procedures and authority of Special Court to be used while 
registering  corruption  cases;  and  provision  for  impeachment  of  persons  appointed  by  His 
Majesty the King under the recommendation of the Constitutional Council and sitting judges. On 
17  August  2002,  the  CIAA  executed  a  major  raid  against  22  Government  officials  from  the 
Ministry of Finance less than 24 hours after the new CIAA Act received  the Royal assent. The 
CIAA  also  initiated  investigation  and  filed  charge  sheets  against  former  ministers,  senior 
bureaucrats, civil servants, and other public officials in the special court. 

 
17. 
The  Government  constituted  a  Judicial  Property  Probe  Commission  in  April  2002  to 
probe  the  property  of  all  post-1990  (after  advent  of  multiparty  democracy)  high-ranking 
government officials, political appointees, ministers, municipal mayors and deputy mayors, and 
chiefs of the district development committees and their families. The overall objective of setting 
up  the  Commission  was  to  discourage  accumulation  of  wealth  through  unfair  means  by 
individuals  who  have  access  to  power  and  privilege.  It  was  a  move  to  identify  and  check 
corruption.  Approximately  40,000  forms  have  been  circulated  to  retired  and  working  public 
officials  and  they  have  been  asked  to  submit  detailed  statements  supported  by  documentary

completed  its  work.  The  Commission  was  dissolved  after  the  submission  of  the  report.  His 
Majesty  the  King  handed  over  the  Commission’s  report  to  the  Prime  Minister  for  necessary 
action. On 1 May 2003, the Government handed over the Commission’s report to the CIAA. The 
CIAA on 14 May 2003 summoned around 40 high-ranking political leaders and civil servants for

18. 
The  amended  Anti-Corruption  Act  of  2002  includes  a  provision,  which  requires  all 
national  servants  (including  civil  servants)  to  submit  a  statement—supported by documentary 
evidence—of  their  wealth/property  held  in  their  name  or  in  anyone  else’s  name.  The 
Government  recently  established  a  National  Vigilance  Center  in  the  Prime  Minister’s  Office  to 
effectively  monitor  anti-corruption  initiatives  and  to  build  public  awareness  against  corruption. 
Among the responsibilities of the Center, a major one is monitoring the income and wealth of all 
public officials.  
 
19. 
The  Government  has  initiated  actions  to  strengthen  the  CIAA  by  providing  additional 
staff,  information  and  communication  technology,  and  training  opportunities.  In  addition,  the 
Government  has  introduced  a  system  of  independent  physical  auditing  of  civil  works, 
amendment  of  financial  administration  rules,  and  formation  of  a  judicial  committee  to  probe 
public officials’ ownership of property. Reforms in the judicial system for an enhanced rule of law 
have  been  planned  as  well.  Under  the  GRP,  the  Government  is  expected  to  table  new 
legislation on financial audit of political parties and anti-money laundering.  
 
20. 
Despite  the  range  of  reforms  undertaken  by  the  Government,  corruption  remains  a 
critical  challenge  to  good  governance  in  the  country  because  preventive  measures  are 
inadequate  and  actions  initiated  against  the  corrupt  have  been  ineffective  and  inadequate. 
Although  political  leaders’  pronouncements  frequently  include  promises  to  combat  corruption, 
there is no evidence of a well-integrated and concentrated effort. The problem is intensified by 
lack of properly worked-out measures/actions, noninvolvement of civil society in the fight against 
corruption, and general lack of transparency and accountability.

A. 
 
Nepal  is  currently  facing  difficulty  in  implementing  the  poverty  reduction  strategy 
1. 
embodied in the Tenth Plan. The fiscal situation has deteriorated sharply due to internal security 
problems,  uncertain  global  conditions,  and  a  precipitous  slowdown  in  economic  growth.  The 
resource  crunch  has  sharply  reduced  the  development  expenditure,  which  is  currently  much 
lower  than  that  required  to  meet  the  Tenth  Plan’s  targets.    This  is  adversely  affecting  the 
Government’s  ability  to  deliver  social  services  and  combat  poverty.  The  problems  are  further 
compounded by lack of good governance. The Public Sector Management Program (PSMP) will 
assist the Government in improving its fiscal position, improve the effectiveness of resource use 
for  economic  development,  and  improve  governance.  In  the  absence  of  the  policy  measures 
suggested  in  the  PSMP,  the  fiscal  situation  is  likely  to  further  deteriorate,  development 
expenditure  would  drop,  resource  use  for  development  would  be  ineffective,  and  key 
governance  constraints  would  remain  unresolved.  In  fact,  the  Government  would  be  in  a  very 
weak  position  to  implement  the  Tenth  Plan,  as  its  capacity  to  provide  basic  social services 
would be considerably weakened, and poverty reduction efforts would have minimal impact on 
poverty reduction and human resource development. 
 
In line with the resource requirements of the Tenth Plan, the Government needs to raise 
2. 
the  revenue/gross  domestic  product  ratio  by  2%  points  over  the  Plan  period.  If  that  is  not 
accomplished, resources will be insufficient to meet the development expenditure target of the

implement  a  comprehensive  Revenue  Mobilization  Action  Plan,  the  existing  fiscal  situation 
would not show perceptible improvement. Revenue losses due to low customs valuation, wide 
range  of  exemptions,  and  leakages  would  continue.  The  PSMP  also  seeks  to strengthen the 
Internal Revenue Department by filling the essential positions, which are currently vacant. In the

Government in addressing the various constraints hampering divestment.

Thematic:                             Good Governance 

 
ADB conducted an in-depth poverty analysis of the country before signing the Poverty Partnership Agreement. Based 
on  the  Nepal  Living  Standards  Survey  (1996),  the  Government  defines  the  threshold  for  poverty  at  an  annual  per 
capita income of NRs4,404. People below this threshold have been estimated at 38% at the end the Ninth Plan period 
(FY1997-FY2002).  Large  segments  of  the  poor  are  hard  core  or  chronic,  barely  managing  a  subsistence  living  on 
fragile  and  vulnerable  ecosystems.  Large  parts  of  the  country  lack  even  the  most  basic  infrastructure,  which  is 
reflected by very low socio economic indicators in certain districts.  
 
There are wide variations in poverty based on rural-urban divide, gender, geography, ethnic group, and occupational 
caste.  About  44%  of  the  rural  households  and  23%  of  the  urban  households  are  estimated  to  lie  below  the  poverty 
line. Given that close to 88% of the total population reside in rural areas, poverty is much more widespread in the rural 
areas.  While  poverty  does  not  vary  much  between  the  hill  and  Terai  regions,  it  is  much  higher  in  the  mountainous 
region. Distribution of poverty incidence across the five development regions indicates that the number of households 
below  the  poverty  line  in  the  eastern  and  central  development  regions  are  less  than  those  in  other  development 
regions.  There  are  more  poor  people  in  the  remote  rural  western  part  of  the  country.  Poverty  incidence  is  higher 
among  the  people  belonging  to  the  lower  caste  groups,  ethnic  minorities.  Weak  governance,  low  growth  rate,  high 
population growth rate, urban-centered growth, and inadequate socio economic infrastructure are some of the reasons 
for the perpetuation of poverty in Nepal.  
 
Weak governance is a major impediment to the poverty reduction efforts . Empowerment of people, accountability and 
transparency  in  resource  use,  prioritizing  and  closely  monitoring  public  expenditures,  streamlining  the  civil  service, 
strengthening  decentralization  for  better  delivery  of  public  services,  and  controlling  corruption  are  some  of  the 
important  measures  in  improving  weak  governance.  Adopting  these  measures  will  reduce  the  gap  in  poverty  level 
between rural and urban areas, between sexes, and lead to better regional balance in development.

Narrative:  The Program supports effective implementation of the Tenth Plan, at a time when the Government is facing a severe resource crunch to pursue its 
poverty  reduction  strategy.  To  help  the  Government  implement  the  core  elements  of  the  Tenth  Plan  and  sharpen  the  poverty  reduction  impact,  the  Program 
supports the prioritization of projects by poverty-based criteria, disengagement of Government from PEs, higher allocation of resources for social priority sectors 
such as basic education, good governance including decentralization, and poverty-based block grant to the local bodies.  
 
Net Impacts:  The Program is expected to have a positive overall net impact on the opportunities for the poor to improve their income and social indicators. The 
direct impact of the Program will be largely pro-poor, giving them better access to public services, and greater transfer of resources to backward and poor areas. 
The  indirect  impact  can  be  generally  pro-poor,  as  the  majority  of  the  population  is  considered  poor.  The  actions  taken  under  the  Program  will  contribute  to 
institution  building  for  efficient  public  sector  administration  and  policy  making  conducive  to  private-sector-led  economic  growth,  which  will  naturally  reduce 
aggregate  poverty.  Indirect  impacts  can  benefit  the  poor  disproportionately  through  improved  access  to  public  services  that  have  otherwise  been  limited  to  the 
urban population.
